Notes: The learned word rótula ('kneecap' in both Sp. and Port.) is from the same root as Spanish rodilla. Sp. de hinojos 'kneeling' is from the same source as Port. joelho.

Spanish: carretera < carreta + ‑era < carro < Lat. carrus < Gaulish carros

Notes: Brazilian Port. uses varejista

Portuguese: saldos, liquidação < Ita. saldo < soldo, Lat. liquidus

Spanish: abarrotero Uncertain < Lat. or < Pre-Roman barra
comida orgánica < Lat. + Greek comeder+organĭcum < órganon
Portuguese: alimentação biológica, Bio < Lat. + Greek alere + βίος+λογία
Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use orgânica.
Spanish also has cuero. Portuguese pele usually means 'skin' or 'fur', but it can also mean 'leather'.
Brazilian Port. tends to use ralé, gentalha

Spanish: comisaría (de policía) < Lat. + Gr. comissarius + politia < πολιτεία
Portuguese: esquadra, posto de polícia < Lat. + Gr. ex-quadrata, positus + politia < πολιτεία
Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use delegacia (de polícia)
Brazilian Por. uses furadeira

Portuguese: martelo demolidor < Lat. martulus demolitio + dor

Spanish: árbol de levas < Lat. arbōs + levare
Portuguese: árvore de cames < Lat. + Germanic arbōs + kamm

Notes: In zoology, Port. also uses brânquias (branchiae).
Spanish also has ganso.

Portuguese: frango < Probably Fr. francolin < Ita. francolino, all of uncertain origin

Notes: Portuguese lâmpada usually means 'light bulb' (except in certain idioms, like lâmpada de Aladino, i.e., 'Aladdin's lamp')
Portuguese 'comida' means food

Portuguese: coruja (*maybe from Lat. cunicularis) of uncertain origin

Spanish: perrera < uncertain origin, perhaps Pre-Roman. perro + era

Notes: Port. also has solo.

Portuguese: gabinete, escritório < Occitan, Lat. cabana, scriptōrium

Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use térreo

Spanish: flotador < Fr. + Sp. suffix flotter + dor
Portuguese: boia < Old Fr. bouée < Frankish baukan
relatório < Lat. relatus + ório suffix < refferre

Notes: Span. also has prisión and Port. archaic cárcere.

Spanish: ardilla < Pre-Roman harda or probably Berber aġárda
zaquizamí,[10] buhardilla < Hisp-Ar. سقف في السماء (saqf fassamā), < Lat. bufus < buharda
Portuguese: água-furtada, mansarda < Lat. aquam + furtus, < Fr. mansarde < François Mansart (architect)

Notes: Port. also has menta.
Brazilian Port. uses açougue
Portuguese 'navalha' means razor.

Portuguese: saia < Lat. sagum < Celtic sagos, sag
sala de operações, sala de cirurgia, bloco operatório < Ger + Lat. sal + operatio, < Ger + Gr. sal + χειρουργική, < Ger + Lat. bluk(k)an + operatio

Spanish: investigación con células madre < Lat. vestigium + cum + cellula + mater
Portuguese: pesquisa de células estaminais < Lat. perquirere + de + cellula + staminis
Notes: Brazilian Por. uses pesquisa de células tronco

Spanish: terco or testarudo < Lat. testa + rudis
meseta < Lat. mensa + Sp. suffix eta

Portuguese: vaga < Gothic vega[13] or < Old Norse vágr,[14] both from Ancient Germanic 'vigan' to shake
Notes: Both in Brazilian Por. and European Por. onda is used

Portuguese: vassoura, giesta, carqueja < Lat. verrere, < Lat. genista, < Maybe Lat. quercus
repórter < Eng. reporter < Medieval Fr. reporteur
Notes: Spanish also has reportero
Port. cabaça means 'calabash
Port. also has calamar

Spanish: en otro lugar < Lat. in alter localis, en alguna parte < Lat. in aliquis unos pars, en ningún lugar < Lat. in nec unus localis
Portuguese: alhures < Provençal alhors, algures < Lat. + Provençal aliquod + hors, nenhures < Lat. + Provençal nec + hors
relvado, grama < Lat. relevare, < Lat. gramen

Spanish: tarjeta < Fr. targe + diminutive suffix eta
Portuguese: cartão, carta < Gr. χάρτης < Lat. charta

Notes: Port. also has filé
Sp. also has remordimiento and Port. also has arrependimento

Spanish: maletero < Old Fr. + Sp. suffix malle + eta + ero
Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use porta-malas or bagageira

Spanish: guantero < Frankish + Sp. suffix want + ero

Notes: Sp. magro means 'lean', in reference to meat
Port. also has superfície.

Spanish: fruto de la pasión < Lat. fructa + passio
Notes: Sp. also has maracuyá
Lat. ventānam 'wind opening' < ventus 'wind'. Lat. iānuella is a diminutive of iānua 'door, opening' (the same root as Eng. January and janitor) < the name ianus, the God of gates or doors.
Sp. balcón means 'balcony'

Meaning: to disrupt, to get in the way (of someone/smthg)

Notes: Port. borrar means 'to smudge'; cf. Sp. borroso 'blurry'. Sp. apagar means 'to turn off' (a meaning that also exists in Port., e.g. apagar a luz 'to turn off the light').
Olvidar also exists in Port. (but is far less common). A learned cognate, obliterar, exists in both languages.

Portuguese: atirar, pôr < Gothic/Suebian taíran, < Lat. ponere < pono

Notes: Por. uses roncar for very loud snoring in humans or animal sounds i.e. pigs
Sp. also has simple.
Port. also has temor.
Port. colheita and recolha (both < Lat. collecta) generally refer to the harvest of crops, wine or data collection (i.e. online surveys, personal data).

Port. also has negro and Sp. also has prieto. Use and connotation vary greatly (i.e. the use of preto to refer to people of African descent is considered a slur in Port. but the prieto in Sp. can often mean "dark", "tan", or "swarthy" in a similar fashion to moreno in both Sp. and Port.).

Portuguese: perto perh. < Lat. *prettus, alteration of pressus 'compressed'

Spanish: juguete < Lat. + Sp. suffix iocus + ete

Portuguese: cabeleireiro < cabeleira 'head of hair; wig' < cabelo < Lat. capillus
Notes: Port. peruca means 'wig'

Portuguese: chávena < Malay chãvan < Chinese < chã-kvãn, caneca < Germanic can
Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use xícara < Sp. jícara < Nahuatl xīcalli.

Spanish: tenedor < Lat. + Sp. suffix tenēre + dor
Portuguese: garfo < either via Lat. graphium or < Fr. greffe
doninha < Lat. domina + Port. suffix inha

Notes: Spanish also has campanilla.
Port. also has ruído, particularly for isolated/unexpected sounds or noises

Portuguese: toxicodependente, drogado < Lat. toxicum + dependens, < Fr. drogue
Notes: Both Port. and Sp. have 'toxicomania' for drug addiction

Portuguese: orçamento < Uncertain, Ita. 'orza' or likely Frankish *lurz + Lat. orça[15] + mentum
